text: Martin Scorsesei did a film, a
documentary. I don't know how widely
distributed it is, but it's called My
Voyage to Italy. The film is a
reference, I believe, to one of the
greatest films ever made in the Italian
tradition, Voyage to Italy by Roberto
Roselini. Roselini's film, Voyage to
Italy, is about a couple that's it's
really teetering. Their marriage is on
the brink of a divorce. Ingred Bergman
and George Sanders travel by car from
London to Naples to claim an inheritance
left them by their uncle Homer. And it
becomes this kind of eerie cultural
descent for this cult for this couple
into a world that is alien to them and
yet at the same time reveals the gaping
holes in their emotional
connection. To me, it always represents
the ultimate confrontation between Italy
and the tourist gaze. You know, Italy
has been part of the Grand Tour for
centuries, right? In in the 18th century
and the 19th
century, upper class patrician noble
people from Europe would travel. They
would I, you know, I joke with my
students, I say it was their junior year
abroad. They would go to Italy and spend
months, sometimes years, seeing art
firsthand, uh, you know, learning the
language, seeing these things that they
had spent their youth studying up close
and personal and oftentimes
experimenting with their identities, you
know, that away from to leave their home
countries and and grow emotionally
before going back to real life. Gerta,
for example, the great German writer,
spent a couple years in Italy and he
said it was his rebirth. He says when he
arrived in Rome it was really like you
know uh the day he was born again and
the birth of his aesthetic his
neocclassical aesthetic is is steeped in
this encounter with Rome. I think Martin
Scorsese is a similar figure. This film,
My Voyage to Italy, is an extraordinary
documentary by Scorsesei of his take on
Italian film history. And he takes you
through Fellini,
Antoni, Viscanti, Roselini. And he gives
a really impressive sense of the arc of
Italian film and how these not only does
he interpret them, he plays key scenes
in them. and you get the feeling that he
could not have become a filmmaker
without the experience of Italian film.
Neo realalism is not just something to
be celebrated but it's also a kind of
burden for some of these young directors
because they feel they can't go past
their masters right as Fellini once said
just because you see a shack right and
and some poor people and film them
doesn't mean it's neo realalism right
but it had that that movement had such a
kind of pull on on film history not just
in Italy but throughout the world And
that Scorsesei documentary is really a
testament to someone who's not, you
know, who's it's also, you know, as an
Italian American, he feels a special
connection to it, but how a film
tradition that's not in the country he's
lived most of his life in could still
kind of be his like a film school to
him.
